Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Diploma in Lean Manufacturing - Productive Management with Fundamental Tools
headline: Learn how the Japanese management concept of ‘lean manufacturing’ can boost production in this free online course.
description: This diploma course explains how organizations can embrace a lean culture to raise workplace productivity and efficiency. We begin by explaining the business philosophy of ‘Kaizen’ and discuss how organizations can use it to continually improve. We then cover some fundamental ‘lean’ tools like the ‘5 Ss’, housekeeping, ‘Kanban’, scheduling systems and so on. We examine the ‘quality circles’ through which lean cultural change is achieved.
courseDescription:
This diploma course provides a comprehensive guide to the fundamental philosophies and tools of lean manufacturing. We outline efficiency-boosting measures like the Japanese concept of ‘Kaizen’, the ‘5 Ss’, ‘Kanban’ and ‘quality circles’. 

The course begins by introducing you to the concept of ‘Kaizen’ as we examine its elements and processes with examples of its successful implementation. This course will be of great help to industrial professionals looking to implement the ‘5 Ss’ and ‘Kanban’. We can also help you to understand how ‘quality circles’ can be employed to change your organization’s work culture into a lean one that never stops trying to improve its internal processes. The course also empowers top and middle management to embrace ‘lean’ methods so they can play a leading role within their evolving organizations.

This course can help lean experts and managers to apply cutting-edge manufacturing concepts to their organizations to boost productivity. These ideas have proven successful in both large and small companies and can prove the difference between success and failure in today’s cutthroat business environment so sign up to get an edge over the competition.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

• After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Narrate benefits of the 5S implementation program.
    • Describe the history of the 5S concept.
    • Explain the implementation models of Hiroyuki Hirano and Takashi Osada.
    • Clarify the meaning of 6S. 
    • Discuss the importance of 5S implementation program.
    • List the important steps for 5S initialization.
    • Review the foundations of the 5S program.
    • State the steps in making a 5S project plan.
    •  Describe the important elements of 5S training for workers.
  • The 5S System
  • The 5S approach has evolved as a methodology for house keeping, and improving workplace efficiency by improving work layouts and inducing the culture of continuous improvement. The 5S system is a comprehensive work-floor management tools. The 5S system not only focuses on how to bring improvement, and to reduce the cycle time of repetitive operations but also incorporates tools to induce the concept of improvement in organization's culture. It comprises of 5 different "S". Each "S" has its meaning, philosophy and implementation methodology.
    • The first "S" means Sort (in Japanese it is known as Seiri).
    • The second "S" means Set In Order (in Japanese it is known as Seiton).
    • The third "S" means Shine (in Japanese it is known as Seiso).
    • The fourth "S" means Standardize (in Japanese it is known as Seiketsu).
    • The fifth "S" means Sustain/Self-discipline (in Japanese it is known as Shitsuke).

  • Benefits of 5S Implementation
  • 5S from its very beginning is focused on minimizing or removing nonvalue articles and processes by developing standard methods for doing the daily work. A robust 5S program enhances quality, efficiency, workflow, and workplace safety. Some of the benefits of 5S implementation are:
    • No need to spend time in finding out the missing tools due to unorganized work-space.
    • Reduces the workflow movement or walking to do repetitive tasks.
    • Enhances floor safety by taking off bending, stretching, and tripping hazards.
    • Enhances the reliability of equipment and machines.
    • Each step is standardized for easier implementation and easy to follow processes for new bees.
    • Frees the cluttered space and thus offers more floor space.
    • Embeds a culture of continuous improvement within the organization.

  •  The key points from this module are:
    • Two models for implementation of 5S systems have been used, one was from Hiroyuki Hirano and the other was from Takashi Osada.
    •  At a time when a single ship was produced in several months, Venetian Arsenal in Venice, Italy, used to produce a ship in one single day by the sixteenth century.
    •  The French term “mise en place”, which is commonly used in cooking, means “putting in place”.
    •  Charles A. Goodrich was an American writer and Congregational minister. He, in 1827, spread the notion of “a place for everything and everything in its place in his "call to action" popular article titled "Neatness".
    • New Tab
      Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • Toyota Production System
      Toyota's production system is also being credited as the basis for the formation of the 5S system methodology and practices, among many other lean methodologies and practices.
      Toyota's production system is also being credited as the basis for the formation of the 5S system methodology and practices, among many other lean methodologies and practices.
    • Hirano's Contribution
      Hirano provided a systematic structure for 5S initiatives and improvement programs. He identified a series of distinct steps, each step reliant on its earlier step.
      Hirano provided a systematic structure for 5S initiatives and improvement programs. He identified a series of distinct steps, each step reliant on its earlier step.
    • Takashi's Contribution
      Takashi Osada wrote a renowned book titled as "The 5S's: Five Keys to a Total Quality Environment". Industry lean practitioners and commentators acknowledged that one can initiate a 5S movement on a workplace with this book.
      Takashi Osada wrote a renowned book titled as "The 5S's: Five Keys to a Total Quality Environment". Industry lean practitioners and commentators acknowledged that one can initiate a 5S movement on a workplace with this book.

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss 1S - Sort philosophy.
    • Explain the steps of 1S - Sort implementation program.
    • Discuss the objectives of the Red tag event, tools required and details about the red-tagged area.
    • Compare the before and after of the 1S - Sort implementation program.
    • Discuss 2S - Set in Order philosophy.
    • Explain the steps of 2S - Set in Order implementation program.
    • Discuss the visual standards used for "Set in Order".
    • Draw spaghetti diagram for plotting the "current state".
    • Propose actions for the "future state".
    • Compare the before and after of the 2S - Set in Order implementation program.

  • 1S Sort - Philosophy
  • The sort is the first of the five foundations of the 5S program. During this phase of the program, the 5S team will visit the selected or designated area and remove everything not required for everyday operations. The more jumble the team removes, the smoother the subsequent process (2S - Set in Order) will be. Additionally, it makes the area easier to manage and safer to work in.

    The 5S tool most commonly utilized during the Sort process is a 5S Red Tag. This tag is utilized as a means to record the status of an article that is not required in a specific area. The tagged items are then shifted to a Red Tag Area often labelled with a Red Tag Area Sign.

    Example of a 5S red tag and red tag area sign are shown in the coming pages.

  • 2S Set in order - Philosophy
  • Set in Order is fundamentally the process of re-arranging the work area so that equipment, tools, and materials are placed at the application point, at the most appropriate distance with all visual label controls in place so as to make misfit items quickly noticed.

    During this phase, one will visit the designated area and order items such as equipment, tools, and supplies at the application point and label them so anyone can understand which area is designated for which of the items.

    • 1S Sort - Important Steps 
      • Capture images before the beginning of the event in the area
      .• List the names of the team members who attended the event
      .• Remind and reinforce the benefits of Sort with the team.
      • Conduct the team activity of how to fill out a 5S red tag properly
      .• Start the red tag event
      • Capture images after the event of the area as well as the new red tag area
      .• Share and learn the thoughts of your team on lessons learned
      .• Display “before and after” comparison on 5S Communication Board in that area.

      • Capture images before the beginning of the event in the area
      .• List the names of the team members who attended the event
      .• Remind and reinforce the benefits of Sort with the team.
      • Conduct the team activity of how to fill out a 5S red tag properly
      .• Start the red tag event
      • Capture images after the event of the area as well as the new red tag area
      .• Share and learn the thoughts of your team on lessons learned
      .• Display “before and after” comparison on 5S Communication Board in that area.

    • 2S Sort - Important Steps 
      • Make your present state spaghetti diagram.
      • Conduct a Circle study activity.
      • Take ideas from the team on work-flow challenges.
      • Identify how and where to lay-out tools and machinery and place accordingly.
      • Keep underutilized 5S materials in the specified cabinet, or whatever place you have decided.
      • Capture after images of the 2S and post it on the comparison template.
      • Discuss with the team about the lessons learned and future ideas of this activity.

    • Discuss 3S - Shine philosophy.
    • Explain the steps of 3S - Shine implementation program.
    •  Compare the before and after of the 3S - Shine implementation program.
    • Discuss 4S - Standardization philosophy.
    • Explain steps of 4S - Standardization implementation program.
    •  Elaborate the requirement for audit to ensure standardization.
    • Discuss 5S shine map and way for allocating responsibilities.
    • Discuss 5S Maintenance Chart and why it is beneficial to the system.

  • 3S Shine - Philosophy
  • This phase is often done with 2S - Set in Order. In Japanese, it is defined as "Seiso". Companies use to combine these two in one event. During this step, the team will focus on "Shine", they have to make all equipment and machinery look as good as new when they are done with 3S. They need to scrub all equipment, machinery, floors, walls, doors, windowsills, cabinets and almost everything.

    The goals of this 5S foundation are:
    • Avoid demolition.
    • Maintain the area to ensure safe and easy work.
    • Maintain the area neat and clean
    • The area should please the workers to work in.
    • Anyone in place, acclimated of that work environment must be capable to identify any problems within fifty feet in five seconds.

  • 3S Shine - Philosophy
  • This phase is often done with 2S - Set in Order. In Japanese, it is defined as "Seiso". Companies use to combine these two in one event. During this step, the team will focus on "Shine", they have to make all equipment and machinery look as good as new when they are done with 3S. They need to scrub all equipment, machinery, floors, walls, doors, windowsills, cabinets and almost everything.

    The goals of this 5S foundation are:
    • Avoid demolition.
    • Maintain the area to ensure safe and easy work.
    • Maintain the area neat and clean
    • The area should please the workers to work in.
    • Anyone in place, acclimated of that work environment must be capable to identify any problems within fifty feet in five seconds.

  • 4S Standardization - Philosophy
  • Standardization is the fourth foundation of 5S. In Japanese it is known as "Seiketsu". The purpose is to standardize the processes utilized to sort, set in order and shine phase of the 5S. During this phase one will make processes that help to spot the deviation from the level achieved by the initial three phases. This is an important step that should not be taken for granted. Lacking adequate standards, workers will not know what is needed from them. One needs to demonstrate explicit and clear expectations for the workers. This is the only way forward to have an effective 5S program.

    The goal of standardization is to develop procedures and schedules to ascertain the optimization the implemented initial phases in the 5S program. If standardization is not done things will return to its prior situation means the Zero point of the 5S program.

  • The key points from this module are:  
    • New Tab

    • 3S Shine Important Steps 
      • Implement the event Shine after setting everything in order.
      • Prepare all materials.
      • Clean all equipment, tools, walls and floors.
      • Inspect all equipment, machinery etc.
      • Paint equipment and walls
      • Send maintenance repair request for issues arising from the inspection.
      • Capture after images and put them in comparison form.
      • Place the comparison form on the communication board.
      • Discuss with team lessons learned and improvement in future.
      • Implement the event Shine after setting everything in order.
      • Prepare all materials.
      • Clean all equipment, tools, walls and floors.
      • Inspect all equipment, machinery etc.
      • Paint equipment and walls
      • Send maintenance repair request for issues arising from the inspection.
      • Capture after images and put them in comparison form.
      • Place the comparison form on the communication board.
      • Discuss with team lessons learned and improvement in future.
    • 4S Standardize - Important Steps 
      • Make Area's 5S Shine Map.
      • Divide area 5S Shine Map into quadrants and allocate each member responsibilities.
      • Involve team and make a 5S Maintenance Chart.
      • Initiate team discussion on the 5S Audit program including the benefits along with a review of the Audit form and scoring.
      • Perform a 5S Audit as a team.
      • Examine the audit score with the team and finalize results with them.
      • Feed the area audit score in the 5S Audit Score Graph.
      • Display the graph on the 5S communication board or achievement board.
      • Make Area's 5S Shine Map.
      • Divide area 5S Shine Map into quadrants and allocate each member responsibilities.
      • Involve team and make a 5S Maintenance Chart.
      • Initiate team discussion on the 5S Audit program including the benefits along with a review of the Audit form and scoring.
      • Perform a 5S Audit as a team.
      • Examine the audit score with the team and finalize results with them.
      • Feed the area audit score in the 5S Audit Score Graph.
      • Display the graph on the 5S communication board or achievement board.
  • After completing this module, you will be able to:  
    • Discuss 5S - Sustain philosophy.
    • Explain the steps of 5S - Sustain implementation program. 
    • Discuss the recognition and reward system of sustain program.
    • Explain how audit results will be used to help Sustain program.
    • Discuss the role of top management in the 5S program.
    • Elaborate on top management can be involved in 5S programs through Gemba Walk.
    • Define Gemba walk and list the steps of Gemba walk.
    • Outline, why the 5S how includes 6th "S" as safety and what is the basis of its inclusion. 
    • Communicate on what basis a 5S program can help implementation of ISO 9001 and ISO 45001. 

  • 5S Sustain - Philosophy
  • Sustain is the fifth and last pillar of 5S. It incorporates the sciences required to keep the improvements and never to return back. Sustaining makes the process of keeping standardized procedures engraved in the daily operation of the workplace. Although it seems like the most difficult part, once done 5S will be much easier than ever before. Many companies successfully complete the first three foundations of the 5S program:
    • Sort
    • Set in Order
    • Shine

    Few companies also keep up with Standardization which is the fourth "S". But, most of the companies have problems with sustaining the improvements. However, it is, in reality, a much easier procedure than most people think.

    Jim Rohn says, “What’s easy to do, is also easy NOT to do.”

    Unfortunately, most of the senior management does not comprehend the importance of Sustaining a 5S program. If they prioritize and allow the people to continue working on its principles with due partial dedication, the team will be able to Sustain. Most of the times when the 5S project is completed, nobody then bothers, sometimes then due to the pressure of the senior management, the scheduled 5S audits are skipped, the maintenance programs are rolled back and this 5S program starts retreating from the progress it has made.

  • Role of Top Management
  • The role of top management is important in every improvement project. If you are going for ISO 9001 - Quality Management System implementation project or with ISO 45001 - Health and Safety management system implementation project, all such international standards require top management commitment for the success of the project. Similarly, a 5S project is also one that requires commitment, support and facilitation from the top management.

    Therefore 5S gurus exclaim that the leadership should drive the project from the top to bottom and also they need to "Walk the Talk". Sometimes they also have to get involved with workers during Gemba walk. We will discuss the details on Gemba walk in coming pages.

  • 5S in Occupational Safety
  • The initial five in a 5S workplace organization and housekeeping methodology means the five foundation which are sort, set in order, shine, standardize and sustain. As the /modern industry is now considering the 6th "S" which is the Safety and it is the honorary sixth “S.”Storage Conditions

    • Storage Conditions
      Good Storage conditions play a vital role in implementing waste management and ensuring safety. Good storage condition is one of the key outcome of 5S program. The 5S program helps good storage conditions in workplace inventory management. By implementing 5S in inventories, every material has its defined place.

      For example in a raw material inventory, goods waiting for inspection are placed in Quarantine area, goods rejected are placed in the rejected area and similarly approved goods are placed in the issuance area. Goods no longer in inventory needed are disposed through red tagged area.

      Each type of good has specific area designated for its storage. For instance, a rejected wire bundle will not be placed in walkways or with approved packaging material. Good storage conditions empower safety by eliminating tripping, falling, and other hazards.
      Good Storage conditions play a vital role in implementing waste management and ensuring safety. Good storage condition is one of the key outcome of 5S program. The 5S program helps good storage conditions in workplace inventory management. By implementing 5S in inventories, every material has its defined place.

      For example in a raw material inventory, goods waiting for inspection are placed in Quarantine area, goods rejected are placed in the rejected area and similarly approved goods are placed in the issuance area. Goods no longer in inventory needed are disposed through red tagged area.

      Each type of good has specific area designated for its storage. For instance, a rejected wire bundle will not be placed in walkways or with approved packaging material. Good storage conditions empower safety by eliminating tripping, falling, and other hazards.
      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • Labeling and Identification
      Labeling and identification in a 5S program helps the identification of hazardous materials. The mishandling of that can cause a health and safety accident. For example if there is an acid tank, the 5S program has already labeled and identified those containers as acid and a standard instruction for use would have been visible.
      Labeling and identification in a 5S program helps the identification of hazardous materials. The mishandling of that can cause a health and safety accident. For example if there is an acid tank, the 5S program has already labeled and identified those containers as acid and a standard instruction for use would have been visible.

  • The key points from this module are:

    Important steps of 5S Sustain program are:
    • Sign a 5S banner with a team and display the banner in the area as a matter of commitment.
    • Display 5S visual assistance and reminders.
    • Establish 5S status communication methods for instance newsletters and status update in executive meetings.
    • Make a 5S Communication Board.
    • Establish a Reward and Recognition program for 5S.
    • The team lead has to lead by example along with member participation, mentoring and coaching.
